summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against Jason Zank, a citizen of the United States, and Liz Lopez Moreno, an Ecuadorian citizen, in a related case.  The court found that Zank violated the Hague Convention, which requires the return of a child from an abduction to a country where the child has become accustomed to living.  According to the court's order, Zank failed to file a Hague Convention petition in violation of the provisions of the Convention.  Zank also failed to show that he was obstructed in his efforts to obtain permanent custody of BLZ in Ecuador.  In a parallel action, the U.N. Secretary of State's Office today announced that it has issued an order suspending Zank from participating in the repatriation of children from foreign countries.  On August 10, 2016, the court granted Zank the right to return BLZ to Ecuador, without admitting or denying Zank’s claims.  As alleged in the court order, BLZ was not a habitual resident of Ecuador when she was taken to Ecuador in 2004 and subsequently retained there in 2016, and Zank was not present during that action when he learned that she had been removed from her habitual residence in Ecuador in 2009 and that she was a drug user who had realized that Lopez Moreno had abducted her in that country when she had realized she had lost her mother to Lopez Moreno.   The Court also found that, in the absence of any Hague Convention relief, Zanks could not have brought an action in an Ecuador-based court.  It also ruled that, based on the facts of the case, ZANK could not petition for permanent custody in Ecuador for purposes of obtaining a court order requiring Zank to repatriate BLZ, and that he could not file a petition with the Ecuadorian court for a court-ordered repatriation.  Finally, the Court found that in the case Zank did not have sufficient evidence to convince the court that he had acted in the best interest of the child when he was abducted from a previous residence, and therefore could not bring an action with the court there.  Further, the judgment also found Zank liable for violations of the Hague Rules of Practice, which require a court to determine whether a person has a legitimate right to a return of an abducted child from a foreign country, including one that is subject to the jurisdiction of the court.
